title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@rstudio.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: GitHub API
text: Use gh() function access API endpoints. endpoints listed documentation. first argument gh() endpoint. can just copy paste API endpoints documentation. Note leading slash must included well. https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/repos#list-repositories---user can copy paste GET /users/{username}/repos gh() call. E.g. JSON result sent API converted R object. Parameters can passed extra arguments. E.g.
code: library(gh) my_repos <- gh("GET /users/{username}/repos", username = "gaborcsardi") vapply(my_repos, "[[", "", "name") #>  [1] "after"         "alexr"         "altlist"       "argufy"        #>  [5] "ask"           "async"         "brokenPackage" "butcher"       #>  [9] "css"           "curl"          "disposables"   "dotenv"        #> [13] "empty"         "falsy"         "finmix"        "franc"         #> [17] "fswatch"       "homebrew-rim"  "ISA"           "keynote"       #> [21] "keypress"      "lpSolve"       "macBriain"     "maxygen"       #> [25] "MISO"          "msgtools"      "multicolor"    "notifier"      #> [29] "odbc"          "parr" my_repos <- gh(   "/users/{username}/repos",   username = "gaborcsardi",   sort = "created") vapply(my_repos, "[[", "", "name") #>  [1] "r-builds"              "homebrew-rim"          "rgdal"                 #>  [4] "readxl"                "sdcHierarchies"        "skopeo"                #>  [7] "playground"            "r-system-requirements" "butcher"               #> [10] "tidyr"                 "empty"                 "rim"                   #> [13] "tidyverse.org"         "finmix"                "tune"                  #> [16] "multicolor"            "pkgdepends"            "css"                   #> [19] "curl"                  "usethis2"              "r-debug"               #> [22] "purrr"                 "redfish"               "win32-console-docs"    #> [25] "vt100-emulator"        "RSQLite"               "pkgload"               #> [28] "rencfaq"               "renv"                  "stockfish"

title: Query the GitHub API — gh
text: extremely minimal client. need know API able use client. function : Try substitute listed parameter endpoint, using {parameter} notation. GET request (default), add listed parameters query parameters. GET request, send parameters request body, JSON. Convert response R list using jsonlite::fromJSON().

title: Query the GitHub API — gh
code: gh(   endpoint,   ...,   per_page = NULL,   .token = NULL,   .destfile = NULL,   .overwrite = FALSE,   .api_url = NULL,   .method = "GET",   .limit = NULL,   .accept = "application/vnd.github.v3+json",   .send_headers = NULL,   .progress = TRUE,   .params = list() )

title: Query the GitHub API — gh
text: endpoint GitHub API endpoint. Must one following forms: METHOD path, e.g. GET /rate_limit, path, e.g. /rate_limit, METHOD url, e.g. GET https://api.github.com/rate_limit, url, e.g. https://api.github.com/rate_limit. method supplied, use .method, defaults "GET". ... Name-value pairs giving API parameters. matched endpoint placeholders, sent query parameters GET requests, JSON body POST requests. one unnamed parameter, raw vector, JSON encoded, sent raw data, . can used example add assets releases. Named NULL values silently dropped. GET requests, named NA values trigger error. methods, named NA values included body request, JSON null. per_page Number items return per page. omitted, substituted max(.limit, 100) .limit set, otherwise determined API (never greater 100). .token Authentication token. Defaults GITHUB_PAT GITHUB_TOKEN environment variables, order set. See gh_token() need flexibility, e.g. different tokens different GitHub Enterprise deployments. .destfile Path write response disk. NULL (default), response processed returned object. path given, response written disk form sent. .overwrite .destfile provided, whether overwrite existing file.  Defaults FALSE. .api_url Github API url (default: https://api.github.com). Used endpoint just contains path. Defaults GITHUB_API_URL environment variable set. .method HTTP method use explicitly supplied endpoint. .limit Number records return. can used instead manual pagination. default NULL, means defaults GitHub API used. can set number request (less) records, also Inf request records. Note, request many records, multiple GitHub API calls used get , can take potentially long time. .accept value Accept HTTP header. Defaults "application/vnd.github.v3+json" . Accept given .send_headers, used. parameter can used provide custom media type, order access preview feature API. .send_headers Named character vector header field values (except Authorization, handled via .token). can used override augment default User-Agent header: "https://github.com/r-lib/gh". .progress Whether show progress indicator calls need one HTTP request. .params Additional list parameters append .... easier use ... parameters list already.

title: Query the GitHub API — gh
text: Answer API gh_response object, also list. Failed requests generate R error. Requests generate raw response return raw vector.

#>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "In an edge case when `by` does not exist, `group_by()` works for `NULL` but not `left_join()`, and `character()` works for `left_join()` but not `group_by()`. Life will be easy if the behavior of these two is consistent. For now I will refer to `merge()` from base and stick with `NULL`.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\na <- tibble::tibble(x = 1)\r\nb <- tibble::tibble(y = 2)\r\na |> dplyr::group_by(NULL) # This works\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 × 1\r\n#>       x\r\n#>   <dbl>\r\n#> 1     1\r\na |> dplyr::group_by(character()) # This does not\r\n#> Error in `dplyr::group_by()`:\r\n#> ! Problem adding computed columns.\r\n#> Caused by error in `mutate()`:\r\n#> ! Problem while computing `..1 = character()`.\r\n#> ✖ `..1` must be size 1, not 0.\r\na |> dplyr::left_join(b, by = NULL) # This does not\r\n#> Error in `dplyr::left_join()`:\r\n#> ! `by` must be supplied when `x` and `y` have no common variables.\r\n#> ℹ use by = character()` to perform a cross-join.\r\na |> dplyr::left_join(b, by = character()) # This works again\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 × 2\r\n#>       x     y\r\n#>   <dbl> <dbl>\r\n#> 1     1     2\r\na |> merge(b, by = NULL) # This works\r\n#>   x y\r\n#> 1 1 2\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-05-12 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\n\r\n", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6267/reactions", #>       "total_count": dbx::dbxConnect(adapter = \"mysql\", host = config$host, user = config$user, password = config$password, port = config$port, dbname = config$dbname)\r\n```\r\n\r\nWe select two columns, collect the data, then group_by the id. \r\nThe filter using n() should isolate cases in which the id_1 has several values of the id_2, and does the job.\r\n\r\n```r\r\ntbl(con, \"my_sql_table\") %>% select(id_1, id_2) %>%\r\n  collect() %>%\r\n  group_by(id_1) %>% filter(n() > 1)\r\n```\r\n\r\nBUT, if the collect() is placed at the end of the code, it is not working any more. \r\n\r\n```r\r\ntbl(con, It just got too out of date to be useful.)\r\nCloses https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/4962\r\nCloses https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/5090\r\nPart of https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/5808\r\n\r\nThis PR adds a `.locale` argument to `arrange()`, with 3 possible options:\r\n- `dplyr_locale()`, the default. See below.\r\n- A single stringi locale identifier, like `\"en_US\"` or `\"fr\"`. This requires stringi.\r\n- `\"C\"`, for sorting in the C locale. This does not require stringi.\r\n\r\n`dplyr_locale()` is a new exported helper and returns a string representing the default locale to use. It has the following properties:\r\n- It defaults to `\"C\"`\r\n- If the `dplyr.locale` option is set to a stringi locale identifier or `\"C\"`, that overrides the above default behavior.\r\n\r\nThis is a breaking change, as we no longer respect the `LC_COLLATE` option.\r\n\r\n- [ ] Run revdeps one more time after we decide that this is The Way", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\n# check_type\r\ncase_when(TRUE ~ 1, TRUE ~ \"x\")\r\n#> Error in names(message) <- `*vtmp*`: 'names' attribute [1] must be the same length as the vector [0]\r\n\r\n# check_class\r\ncase_when(TRUE ~ 1, TRUE ~ structure(1, class = \"foo\"))\r\n#> Error in names(message) <- `*vtmp*`: 'names' attribute [1] must be the same length as the vector [0]\r\n```\r\n\r\nThese are supposed to report on invalid types and classes, respectively.\r\n\r\nThis happens because we are missing an argument here in `replace_with()`. That `NULL` is probably intended to be passed on to `reason`, but it is instead being matched to `name` and that doesn't work. A character name is required for that error path to run correctly.\r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/blob/1cff4b9ce7f404955d8a5764b5708eee5972e0e3/R/case_when.R#L174", #>     "reactions": { #> "created_at": "2022-05-01T09:36:24Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-05-04T16:55:17Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "MEMBER", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "A `summarize()` call can contain more than one call to `across()`, which makes it more powerful than the `_at` and `_if` variants. I still wonder if we need to consider new columns when selecting columns with `across()`. \r\n\r\n## Example\r\n\r\nConsider the following (contrived) example:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\ndata <- tibble(my_summary = 0, xa = 1, xb = TRUE)\r\n\r\ndata %>%\r\n  summarize(\r\n    across(starts_with(\"x\"), sum, .names = \"{.col}_summary\"),\r\n    across(ends_with(\"_summary\"), mean, .names = \"{.col}_summary\")\r\n  )\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 × 5\r\n#>   xa_summary xb_summary my_summary_summary xa_summary_summary xb_summary_summary\r\n#>        <dbl>      <int>              <dbl>              <dbl>              <dbl>\r\n#> 1          1          1                  0                  1                  1\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-05-01 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nThe second `across()` call captures the summary columns created in the first `across()` call. I can't think of a practical use case.\r\n\r\n## Proposal\r\n\r\nShould we limit the columns selectable with `across()` to the original columns in `summarize()`, and perhaps also in `mutate()` (though the case is not as clear there)? In the above example, the `_summary_summary` columns would no longer be created.\r\n\r\n## Motivation\r\n\r\nSeparation of `mutate()` into `build_mutate_spec()` and `mutate_spec()` (same for `summarize()`), so that backends need to implement only `mutate_spec()` and let dplyr do the rest.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": spent in `enquos()`, there is now only one call to that function. This assumes that auto-naming uses `as_label()` .\r\n\r\nThere might be a lot to gain if `rlang:::endots()` is moved to C.\r\n\r\nI tried `exprs_auto_name()`, its slower.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(rlang)\r\n\r\ndplyr_quosures <- function(...) {\r\n  quosures <- enquos(..., .ignore_empty = \"all\")\r\n  names_given <- names2(quosures)\r\n  names_auto <- names(enquos(..., .named = TRUE, .ignore_empty = \"all\"))\r\n\r\n  for (i in seq_along(quosures)) {\r\n    quosures[[i]] <- dplyr:::new_dplyr_quosure(quosures[[i]],\r\n      name_given = names_given[i],\r\n      name_auto = names_auto[i],\r\n      is_named = names_given[i] != \"\",\r\n      index = i\r\n    )\r\n  }\r\n  quosures\r\n}\r\n\r\ndplyr_quosures_new <- function(...) {\r\n  quosures <- enquos(..., .ignore_empty = \"all\")\r\n  names_given <- names2(quosures)\r\n\r\n  for (i in seq_along(quosures)) {\r\n    quosure <- quosures[[i]]\r\n    name_given <- names_given[[i]]\r\n    is_named <- (name_given != \"\")\r\n    if (is_named) {\r\n      name_auto <- name_given\r\n    } else {\r\n      name_auto <- as_label(quosure)\r\n    }\r\n\r\n    quosures[[i]] <- dplyr:::new_dplyr_quosure(quosure,\r\n      name_given = name_given,\r\n      name_auto = name_auto,\r\n      is_named = is_named,\r\n      index = i\r\n    )\r\n  }\r\n  quosures\r\n}\r\n\r\nbench::mark(dplyr_quosures(a = 1), dplyr_quosures_new(a = 1))\r\n#> # A tibble: 2 × 6\r\n#>   expression                     min   median `itr/sec` mem_alloc `gc/sec`\r\n#>   <bch:expr>                <bch:tm> <bch:tm>     <dbl> <bch:byt>    <dbl>\r\n#> 1 dplyr_quosures(a = 1)       78.4µs   82.9µs    11651.    9.04MB     61.2\r\n#> 2 dplyr_quosures_new(a = 1)   37.6µs   40.5µs    23625.   59.44KB     56.8\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-05-01 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Should `arrange()` show a warning on empty or constant criteria?\r\nIt would warn over some common errors.\r\n\r\nArrange with no arguments:\r\n```r\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  arrange()\r\n```\r\n\r\nTrying to arrange by column name:\r\n```r\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  arrange(\"col1\")\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  arrange(col1)\r\n```\r\n\r\nTrying to arrange by column position:\r\n```r\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  arrange(1:3)\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  arrange(across(1:3))\r\n```\r\n\r\nIt would be similar to the warning when `filter` contains an asignment, instead of a condition:\r\n```r\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  filter(col1 = condition)\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  filter(col1 == condition)\r\n```\r\n", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "As identified by @debruine here https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6236#issuecomment-1103972470 this issue is actually caused when mutate() is used after rowwise() and generates warnings.\r\n\r\nThis code takes ~11 seconds to run in a clean R session\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(tictoc)\r\ntic()\r\nfoo <- tibble(\r\n  id = 1:800\r\n) %>% \r\n  rowwise() %>% \r\n  mutate(group_b_mean = mean(NULL))\r\ntoc()\r\n# 11.584 sec elapsed\r\n```\r\n\r\nPlease note that weirdly the same code takes <1second when run with the {reprex} addin.\r\n\r\nMany thanks to debruine "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "See below with comparison to `left_join()` behaviour\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)\r\ndf1 <- tibble(col1 = 1:2, key = letters[1:2])\r\ndf2 <- tibble(col2 = 3:4, key2 = letters[2:3])\r\n\r\nnest_join(df1, df2, by = c(key = \"key2\"), keep = TRUE)\r\n#> # A tibble: 2 × 3\r\n#>    col1 key   df2             \r\n#>   <int> <chr> <list>          \r\n#> 1     1 a     <tibble [0 × 2]>\r\n#> 2     2 b     <tibble [1 × 2]>\r\n\r\nleft_join(df1, df2, by = c(key = \"key2\"), keep = TRUE)\r\n#> # A tibble: 2 × 4\r\n#>    col1 key    col2 key2 \r\n#>   <int> <chr> <int> <chr>\r\n#> 1     1 a        NA <NA> \r\n#> 2     2 b         3 b\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created #>     "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "I have a package that re-exports functions from various places so I can easily use them in some internal packages without having to deal with the separate imports. I can easily work around this issue by not doing that, but the bug surprised me and was invisible without direct testing, so I wanted to report it in case you want to deal with it.\r\n\r\nBasically, if I reexport `desc()`, and I call it by namespacing, it doesn't do anything in `arrange()`.\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# Install my example package that reexports desc.\r\n# devtools::install_github(\"jonthegeek/mydesc\")\r\ndf <- data.frame(x = c(\"first\", \"second\"))\r\ndplyr::arrange(df, dplyr::desc(x))$x[[1]]\r\n#> [1] \"second\"\r\ndplyr::arrange(df, mydesc::desc(x))$x[[1]]\r\n#> [1] \"first\"\r\n```\r\n\r\nIt appears to be an issue with row 98 of arrange.R, but I'm not sure how/if it should be fixed.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "body": "As a heavy SQL user, I'm constantly using argument \"on\" instead of \"by\" in inner_join and left_join. These functions do echo what they're actually joining on, but it's easy to miss. I feel like these functions should stop you in your tracks if you try to use \"on\" or throw a warning and make the substitution.\r\n\r\nBit of a contrived example below, but in both cases it's clear the user is intending to join on \"id\" and not c(\"id\", \"x\")\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\ndf <- data.frame(id = c(1,2), x = c(3.4, 2.6))\r\ndf2 <- data.frame(id = c(1,2), x = c(3.4, 2.7), z = c(4.4, 5.4))\r\n\r\ndf %>% inner_join(df2, on=\"id\")\r\ndf %>% inner_join(df2, by=\"id\")\r\n```\r\n", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": sometimes want to group a `bind_rows` result by the `.id` column. But since the column is a `character`, the default grouping ignores the order that I gave the data in, sorting it instead. Silly toy example:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nbind_rows(\r\n  c = mtcars,\r\n  a = mtcars,\r\n  .id = 'dataset'\r\n) |> group_by(dataset) |> count()\r\n#> # A tibble: 2 × 2\r\n#> # Groups:   dataset [2]\r\n#>   dataset     n\r\n#>   <chr>   <int>\r\n#> 1 a          32\r\n#> 2 c          32\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-05-19 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nI'd expect the order to be `c` then `a` in the summary table. I can work around this by, say, `group_by(dataset = as_factor(dataset))`, but I'm wondering why factor isn't default.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Would it make sense to export a general verb (e.g., `join()` or `join_type()` to avoid conflicts if desired) with a `type` argument, similar to `plyr::join()`? I think this would make it more readable and easier to track the related development such as #5910. It could be a generic that directly utilizes the internal `join_mutate()` and `join_filter()` helper functions while keeping the current `*_join` verbs for backward compatibility. This is similar to `readr::read_delim()` and may be applicable to other verbs. #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "In an edge case when `by` does not exist, `group_by()` works for `NULL` but not `left_join()`, and `character()` works for `left_join()` but not `group_by()`. Life will be easy if the behavior of these two is consistent. For now I will refer to `merge()` from base and stick with `NULL`.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\na <- tibble::tibble(x = 1)\r\nb <- tibble::tibble(y = 2)\r\na |> dplyr::group_by(NULL) # This works\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 × 1\r\n#>       x\r\n#>   <dbl>\r\n#> 1     1\r\na |> dplyr::group_by(character()) # This does not\r\n#> Error in `dplyr::group_by()`:\r\n#> ! Problem adding computed columns.\r\n#> Caused by error in `mutate()`:\r\n#> ! Problem while computing `..1 = character()`.\r\n#> ✖ `..1` must be size 1, not 0.\r\na |> dplyr::left_join(b, by = NULL) # This does not\r\n#> Error in `dplyr::left_join()`:\r\n#> ! `by` must be supplied when `x` and `y` have no common variables.\r\n#> ℹ use by = character()` to perform a cross-join.\r\na |> dplyr::left_join(b, by = character()) # This works again\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 × 2\r\n#>       x     y\r\n#>   <dbl> <dbl>\r\n#> 1     1     2\r\na |> merge(b, by = NULL) # This works\r\n#>   x y\r\n#> 1 1 2\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-05-12 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\n\r\n", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6267/reactions", #>       "total_count": "created_at": "2022-05-12T09:22:46Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-05-12T09:23:29Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Dear community,\r\nI encounter a problem when filtering data on the SQL-server side before a collect() function.\r\n\r\nI am not sure how to create a reproducible example since I would need to create some SQL database.\r\n\r\nStill, I will leave that problem I have here:\r\n\r\nThis command start a connection to a SQL database via the \"con\" handle, like follow (dbx package)\r\n\r\n```r\r\n con <- dbx::dbxConnect(adapter = \"mysql\", host = config$host, user = config$user, password = config$password, port = config$port, dbname = config$dbname)\r\n```\r\n\r\nWe select two columns, collect the data, then group_by the id. \r\nThe filter using n() should isolate cases in which the id_1 has several values of the id_2, and does the job.\r\n\r\n```r\r\ntbl(con, \"my_sql_table\") %>% select(id_1, id_2) %>%\r\n  collect() %>%\r\n  group_by(id_1) %>% filter(n() > 1)\r\n```\r\n\r\nBUT, if the collect() is placed at the end of the code, it is not working any more. \r\n\r\n```r\r\ntbl(con, This previously iterated over data frame input column by column, but we now fully embrace the vctrs definition of a missing value, which is when the entire row is empty for data frames. It just got too out of date to be useful.)\r\nCloses https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/4962\r\nCloses https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/5090\r\nPart of https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/5808\r\n\r\nThis PR adds a `.locale` argument to `arrange()`, with 3 possible options:\r\n- `dplyr_locale()`, the default. See below.\r\n- A single stringi locale identifier, like `\"en_US\"` or `\"fr\"`. This requires stringi.\r\n- `\"C\"`, for sorting in the C locale. This does not require stringi.\r\n\r\n`dplyr_locale()` is a new exported helper and returns a string representing the default locale to use. It has the following properties:\r\n- It defaults to `\"C\"`\r\n- If the `dplyr.locale` option is set to a stringi locale identifier or `\"C\"`, that overrides the above default behavior.\r\n\r\nThis is a breaking change, as we no longer respect the `LC_COLLATE` option.\r\n\r\n- [ ] Run revdeps one more time after we decide that this is The Way", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\n# check_type\r\ncase_when(TRUE ~ 1, TRUE ~ \"x\")\r\n#> Error in names(message) <- `*vtmp*`: 'names' attribute [1] must be the same length as the vector [0]\r\n\r\n# check_class\r\ncase_when(TRUE ~ 1, TRUE ~ structure(1, class = \"foo\"))\r\n#> Error in names(message) <- `*vtmp*`: 'names' attribute [1] must be the same length as the vector [0]\r\n```\r\n\r\nThese are supposed to report on invalid types and classes, respectively.\r\n\r\nThis happens because we are missing an argument here in `replace_with()`. That `NULL` is probably intended to be passed on to `reason`, but it is instead being matched to `name` and that doesn't work. A character name is required for that error path to run correctly.\r\nhttps://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/blob/1cff4b9ce7f404955d8a5764b5708eee5972e0e3/R/case_when.R#L174", #>     "reactions": { #> I'm using the CRAN version of `dplyr` (1.0.9) and R 4.2.0. 224.1915   581.396   100\r\n dplyr 7873.443 8315.1935 10415.7697 8544.3645 10784.3290 50407.269   100\r\n```\r\n", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "created_at": "2022-05-01T09:36:24Z", #>     "updated_at": "2022-05-04T16:55:17Z", #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "MEMBER", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "A `summarize()` call can contain more than one call to `across()`, which makes it more powerful than the `_at` and `_if` variants. I still wonder if we need to consider new columns when selecting columns with `across()`. \r\n\r\n## Example\r\n\r\nConsider the following (contrived) example:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\ndata <- tibble(my_summary = 0, xa = 1, xb = TRUE)\r\n\r\ndata %>%\r\n  summarize(\r\n    across(starts_with(\"x\"), sum, .names = \"{.col}_summary\"),\r\n    across(ends_with(\"_summary\"), mean, .names = \"{.col}_summary\")\r\n  )\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 × 5\r\n#>   xa_summary xb_summary my_summary_summary xa_summary_summary xb_summary_summary\r\n#>        <dbl>      <int>              <dbl>              <dbl>              <dbl>\r\n#> 1          1          1                  0                  1                  1\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-05-01 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nThe second `across()` call captures the summary columns created in the first `across()` call. I can't think of a practical use case.\r\n\r\n## Proposal\r\n\r\nShould we limit the columns selectable with `across()` to the original columns in `summarize()`, and perhaps also in `mutate()` (though the case is not as clear there)? In the above example, the `_summary_summary` columns would no longer be created.\r\n\r\n## Motivation\r\n\r\nSeparation of `mutate()` into `build_mutate_spec()` and `mutate_spec()` (same for `summarize()`), so that backends need to implement only `mutate_spec()` and let dplyr do the rest.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/6253.diff", #>       "patch_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/6253.patch", #>       "merged_at": {} #>     }, #>     "body": "Most of the time is spent in `enquos()`, there is now only one call to that function. This assumes that auto-naming uses `as_label()` .\r\n\r\nThere might be a lot to gain if `rlang:::endots()` is moved to C.\r\n\r\nI tried `exprs_auto_name()`, its slower.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(rlang)\r\n\r\ndplyr_quosures <- function(...) {\r\n  quosures <- enquos(..., .ignore_empty = \"all\")\r\n  names_given <- names2(quosures)\r\n  names_auto <- names(enquos(..., .named = TRUE, .ignore_empty = \"all\"))\r\n\r\n  for (i in seq_along(quosures)) {\r\n    quosures[[i]] <- dplyr:::new_dplyr_quosure(quosures[[i]],\r\n      name_given = names_given[i],\r\n      name_auto = names_auto[i],\r\n      is_named = names_given[i] != \"\",\r\n      index = i\r\n    )\r\n  }\r\n  quosures\r\n}\r\n\r\ndplyr_quosures_new <- function(...) {\r\n  quosures <- enquos(..., .ignore_empty = \"all\")\r\n  names_given <- names2(quosures)\r\n\r\n  for (i in seq_along(quosures)) {\r\n    quosure <- quosures[[i]]\r\n    name_given <- names_given[[i]]\r\n    is_named <- (name_given != \"\")\r\n    if (is_named) {\r\n      name_auto <- name_given\r\n    } else {\r\n      name_auto <- as_label(quosure)\r\n    }\r\n\r\n    quosures[[i]] <- dplyr:::new_dplyr_quosure(quosure,\r\n      name_given = name_given,\r\n      name_auto = name_auto,\r\n      is_named = is_named,\r\n      index = i\r\n    )\r\n  }\r\n  quosures\r\n}\r\n\r\nbench::mark(dplyr_quosures(a = 1), dplyr_quosures_new(a = 1))\r\n#> # A tibble: 2 × 6\r\n#>   expression                     min   median `itr/sec` mem_alloc `gc/sec`\r\n#>   <bch:expr>                <bch:tm> <bch:tm>     <dbl> <bch:byt>    <dbl>\r\n#> 1 dplyr_quosures(a = 1)       78.4µs   82.9µs    11651.    9.04MB     61.2\r\n#> 2 dplyr_quosures_new(a = 1)   37.6µs   40.5µs    23625.   59.44KB     56.8\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2022-05-01 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": cannot be found if we use the formula notation, but is found with a standard anonymous function :\r\n\r\n```\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\n\r\nmutate(band_members, across(1, ~tryCatch(stop(), error = function(e) .)))\r\n#> Error in `mutate()`:\r\n#> ! Problem while computing `..1 = across(1, ~tryCatch(stop(), error =\r\n#>   function(e) .))`.\r\n#> Caused by error in `across()`:\r\n#> ! Problem while computing column `name`.\r\n#> Caused by error:\r\n#> ! object '.' not found\r\n\r\nmutate(band_members, across(1, function(.) tryCatch(stop(), error = function(e) .)))\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 × 2\r\n#>   name  band   \r\n#>   <chr> <chr>  \r\n#> 1 Mick  Stones \r\n#> 2 John  Beatles\r\n#> 3 Paul  Beatles\r\n```\r\n\r\nThis works though: \r\n\r\n```\r\nmap(1, ~tryCatch(stop(), error = #>     "closed_at": {}, #>     "author_association": "NONE", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "Should `arrange()` show a warning on empty or constant criteria?\r\nIt would warn over some common errors.\r\n\r\nArrange with no arguments:\r\n```r\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  arrange()\r\n```\r\n\r\nTrying to arrange by column name:\r\n```r\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  arrange(\"col1\")\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  arrange(col1)\r\n```\r\n\r\nTrying to arrange by column position:\r\n```r\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  arrange(1:3)\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  arrange(across(1:3))\r\n```\r\n\r\nIt would be similar to the warning when `filter` contains an asignment, instead of a condition:\r\n```r\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  filter(col1 = condition)\r\ndf1 %>%\r\n  filter(col1 == condition)\r\n```\r\n", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "As identified by @debruine here https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6236#issuecomment-1103972470 this issue is actually caused when mutate() is used after rowwise() and generates warnings.\r\n\r\nThis code takes ~11 seconds to run in a clean R session\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(tictoc)\r\ntic()\r\nfoo <- tibble(\r\n  id = 1:800\r\n) %>% \r\n  rowwise() %>% \r\n  mutate(group_b_mean = mean(NULL))\r\ntoc()\r\n# 11.584 sec elapsed\r\n```\r\n\r\nPlease note that weirdly the same code takes <1second when run with the {reprex} addin.\r\n\r\nMany thanks to debruine for figuring this out.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6236/reactions", #>       "total_count": 0, #>       "+1": 0, #>       "-1": 0, #> #>     "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR", #>     "active_lock_reason": {}, #>     "body": "I have a package that re-exports functions from various places so I can easily use them in some internal packages without having to deal with the separate imports. I can easily work around this issue by not doing that, but the bug surprised me and was invisible without direct testing, so I wanted to report it in case you want to deal with it.\r\n\r\nBasically, if I reexport `desc()`, and I call it by namespacing, it doesn't do anything in `arrange()`.\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# Install my example package that reexports desc.\r\n# devtools::install_github(\"jonthegeek/mydesc\")\r\ndf <- data.frame(x = c(\"first\", \"second\"))\r\ndplyr::arrange(df, dplyr::desc(x))$x[[1]]\r\n#> [1] \"second\"\r\ndplyr::arrange(df, mydesc::desc(x))$x[[1]]\r\n#> [1] \"first\"\r\n```\r\n\r\nIt appears to be an issue with row 98 of arrange.R, but I'm not sure how/if it should be fixed.", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "body": "As a heavy SQL user, I'm constantly using argument \"on\" instead of \"by\" in inner_join and left_join. These functions do echo what they're actually joining on, but it's easy to miss. I feel like these functions should stop you in your tracks if you try to use \"on\" or throw a warning and make the substitution.\r\n\r\nBit of a contrived example below, but in both cases it's clear the user is intending to join on \"id\" and not c(\"id\", \"x\")\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\ndf <- data.frame(id = c(1,2), x = c(3.4, 2.6))\r\ndf2 <- data.frame(id = c(1,2), x = c(3.4, 2.7), z = c(4.4, 5.4))\r\n\r\ndf %>% inner_join(df2, on=\"id\")\r\ndf %>% inner_join(df2, by=\"id\")\r\n```\r\n", #>     "reactions": { #>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6228/reactions", #>       "total_count": 0, #>       "+1": 0, #>       "-1": 0, #>       "laugh": 0, #>       "hooray": 0, #>       "confused": 0, #>       "heart": 0, #>       "rocket": 0, #>       "eyes": 0 #>     }, #>     "timeline_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/6228/timeline", #>     "performed_via_github_app": {}, #>     "state_reason": {} #>   } #> ]   ## Automatic pagination users <- gh("/users", .limit = 50) length(users) #> [1] 50 if (FALSE) { ## Access developer preview of Licenses API (in preview as of 2015-09-24) gh("/licenses") # used to error code 415 gh("/licenses", .accept = "application/vnd.github.drax-preview+json") } if (FALSE) { ## Access Github Enterprise API ## Use GITHUB_API_URL environment variable to change the default. gh("/user/repos", type = "public", .api_url = "https://github.foobar.edu/api/v3") } if (FALSE) { ## Use I() to force body part to be sent as an array, even if length 1 ## This works whether assignees has length 1 or > 1 assignees <- "gh_user" assignees <- c("gh_user1", "gh_user2") gh("PATCH /repos/OWNER/REPO/issues/1", assignees = I(assignees)) } if (FALSE) { ## There are two ways to send JSON data. One is that you supply one or ## more objects that will be converted to JSON automatically via ## jsonlite::toJSON(). In this case sometimes you need to use ## jsonlite::unbox() because fromJSON() creates lists from scalar vectors ## by default. The Content-Type header is automatically added in this ## case. For example this request turns on GitHub Pages, using this ## API: https://docs.github.com/v3/repos/pages/#enable-a-pages-site  gh::gh(   "POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/pages",   owner = "r-lib",   repo = "gh",   source = list(     branch = jsonlite::unbox("gh-pages"),     path = jsonlite::unbox("/")   ),   .send_headers = c(Accept = "application/vnd.github.switcheroo-preview+json") )  ## The second way is to handle the JSON encoding manually, and supply it ## as a raw vector in an unnamed argument, and also a Content-Type header:  body <- '{ "source": { "branch": "gh-pages", "path": "/" } }' gh::gh(   "POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/pages",   owner = "r-lib",   repo = "gh",   charToRaw(body),   .send_headers = c(     Accept = "application/vnd.github.switcheroo-preview+json",     "Content-Type" = "application/json"   ) ) }

title: Return the local user's GitHub Personal Access Token (PAT) — gh_token
text: gh can find personal access token (PAT) via gh_token(), includes PAT requests. requests succeed without PAT, many require PAT prove request authorized specific GitHub user. PAT also helps rate limiting. gh use casual, want PAT. gh calls gitcreds::gitcreds_get() api_url, checks session environment variables local Git credential store PAT appropriate api_url. Therefore, previously used PAT , e.g., command line Git, gh may retrieve re-use . can call gitcreds::gitcreds_get() directly, , want see found specific URL. matching PAT found, gitcreds::gitcreds_get() errors, whereas gh_token() , instead, returns "". See GitHub's documentation Creating personal access token, use usethis::create_github_token() guided experience, including pre-selection recommended scopes. PAT, can use gitcreds::gitcreds_set() add Git credential store. point , gh (via gitcreds::gitcreds_get()) able find without effort part.

title: gh (development version)
text: gh now accepts lower-case methods .e. gh::gh("get /users/hadley/repos") gh::gh("GET /users/hadley/repos") work (@maelle, #167). Response headers ("response_headers") response content ("response_content") now returned error conditions error handlers can use information, rate limit reset header, handling github_errors (@gadenbuie, #117).

title: gh 1.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2021-04-30 gh now shows correct number records progress bar paginating (#147). New .params argument gh() make easier pass parameters programmatically (#140).

title: gh 1.2.1
text: CRAN release: 2021-04-01 Token validation accounts new format announced 2021-03-04 implemented 2021-04-01 (#148, @fmichonneau).

title: gh 1.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-11-27 gh_gql() now passes arguments gh() (#124). gh now handles responses pagination better, tries properly merge (#136, @rundel). gh can retrieve PAT Git credential store, lookup based targeted API URL. now uses gitcreds package. environment variables consulted URL-specific GitHub PATs changed. “https://api.github.com”: GITHUB_PAT_GITHUB_COM now, instead GITHUB_PAT_API_GITHUB_COM “https://github.acme.com/api/v3”: GITHUB_PAT_GITHUB_ACME_COM now, instead GITHUB_PAT_GITHUB_ACME_COM_API_V3 See documentation gitcreds package details. keyring package longer used, favor Git credential store. documentation GitHub REST API moved https://docs.github.com/rest endpoints now documented using URI template style RFC 6570: Old: GET /repos/:owner/:repo/issues New: GET /repos/{owner}/{repo}/issues gh accepts prioritizes new style. However, still parameter substitution old style. Fixed error occurred calling gh() .progress = FALSE (@gadenbuie, #115). gh() accepts named NA parameters destined request body (#139).

title: gh 1.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-01-24 Raw responses GitHub now returned raw vector. Responses may written disk providing path .destfile argument. gh now sets .Last.error error object uncaught error, .Last.error.trace stack trace error. gh() now silently drops named NULL parameters, throws error named NA parameters (#21, #84). gh() now returns better values empty responses, typically empty lists dictionaries (#66). gh() now .accept argument make easier set Accept HTTP header (#91). New gh_gql() function make easier work GitHub GraphQL API. gh now supports separate personal access tokens GitHub Enterprise sites. See ?gh_token details. gh now supports storing GitHub personal access tokens (PAT) system keyring, via keyring package. See ?gh_token details. gh() can now POST raw data, allows adding assets releases (#56).

title: gh 1.0.1
text: CRAN release: 2017-07-16 First public release.
